Award.AwardTitle: UNS: Sustainable Energy-Intensive Manufacturing via Demand Response Process Operations

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Baldea, 1512379

Energy generation in the United States and across the world is shifting, with the contribution of renewable sources tripling in the past decade. But, renewable sources are inherently variable and their generation rates fluctuate in time due to factors such as wind speed, insolation and cloud cover. Grid energy consumption varies as well, typically reaching a daily peak in the late hours of the afternoon and a minimum in the early morning. To meet this peak demand, grid operators must turn on additional generation facilities (referred to as "peaking plants"), which are typically less efficient and more polluting than base load generators. Balancing fluctuating energy resources and consumers is one of the central motivators behind current efforts to develop and deploy the smart grid, which is predicated on a close integration and synchronization of electricity generation and electricity use. Demand response (DR) strategies, defined by the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) as "Changes in electric usage by demand-side resources from their normal consumption patterns [in response to economic incentives and dynamic pricing structures] at times of high wholesale market prices or when system reliability is jeopardized" will play a key role in coordinating energy generation and consumption in the smart grid. DR is expected to reduce net peak power demand in the US by about 5% (or about 50GW) over the next ten years, with significant sustainability benefits related to eliminating the need for new peaking plants and reducing the use of and emissions from existing ones. This project is aimed at applying DR strategies in an industrial context.

Intellectual Merit: Energy-intensive chemical manufacturing processes (e.g., air separation, ammonia, alumina, chlor-alkali) account for about 10% of industrial
electricity consumption. They are ideally suited for DR initiatives due to their turndown capacity and ability to store energy intensive products. DR requires processes to transition rapidly and remain efficient across a broad operating envelope, in the presence of fluctuations in feedstock quality, product demand and ambient conditions. While the production scheduling problem associated with DR operation has been extensively addressed, the dynamic and control aspects of implementing the resulting schedules have received much less attention. Therefore, the present project aims to i) establish a novel framework for modeling, analyzing and optimizing the dynamics and control of process systems operating under DR and, ii) develop a computationally efficient implementation of the proposed algorithms and validate it on industrially relevant processes (air separation, combined heat and power). These results will be applicable to the analysis and mitigation of dynamic bottlenecks in existing facilities, as well as to new projects. The optimization of the dynamics and control of processes operating involved in DR will be formulated as a dynamic optimization under uncertainty, and solved using an approach inspired by nonlinear systems identification theory. THe approach eschews the traditional use of scenarios to capture uncertainty. Rather, the fluctuations of the uncertain variables will be described as pseudo-random multi-level signals with precisely tuned frequency content, which will be imposed on the process model during the iterations of a dynamic optimization. In this manner, the relevant dynamic modes of the system are selectively excited ("identified") and can be optimally modulated to minimize the expected value of the objective function.

Broader Impact:Through an ongoing partnership with the University of Texas Equal Opportunity in Engineering program, the PI will recruit undergraduate researchers from underrepresented groups, who will acquire valuable experience towards future graduate studies. The concepts developed in the proposal will be incorporated in a course on Mathematical Modeling of Engineered Systems prepared by the PI. A new outreach initiative to provide real-life engineering experiences for middle-school student and parent teams from low-income, minority families is proposed, with the aim of supporting the students? efforts to become first-generation college graduates.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The landscape of electricity generation in the U.S. is shifting, with the contribution of renewable sources tripling in the past decade. Renewable sources are, however, inherently time-variable and their generation rates fluctuate due to changes in, e.g. wind speed, cloud cover. Grid power demand varies as well, typically peaking in the late afternoon and reaching a minimum in the early morning. Balancing fluctuating energy resources and consumers is a key driver behind efforts to deploy the smart grid, which relies, among others, on the integration and synchronization of electricity generation and use. Demand response (DR) strategies, consisting of deliberate changes in user-level electricity demand patterns (e.g., based on changing electricity prices), will play an important role in this context.

Applying DR strategies to industrial electricity users without disrupting the production process/product delivery calls for an energy buffer. Large-capacity electricity storage (e.g., batteries) remains costly. However, chemical processes have turndown capacity and the ability to buffer energy in the form of energy-intensive products, and are ideally suited for DR participation. Electricity-intensive chemical processes (e.g., air separation, ammonia, chlor-alkali, aluminum production) account for more than 10% of the total industrial electricity consumption in the U.S., but only about 50% of industrial DR capacity is currently utilized.

Grid demand and electricity pricing undergo frequent (an hourly basis or faster) and significant changes. Participating in DR requires that chemical processes transition rapidly across a broad set of operating points (corresponding to different power demand levels), and remain efficient in the presence fluctuations in feedstock quality and other operating conditions, and product demand. While the design and scheduling of chemical processes under such uncertainty have been addressed extensively from a steady-state perspective, the dynamics and control of process systems participating in DR operations have received far less attention.

Motivated by the above, the objectives of the present project were twofold:

i) establish a novel algorithmic framework for analyzing and optimizing the dynamics, control and energy use of chemical processes operating under DR

ii) develop a computationally-efficient implementation of these algorithms and validate it on electricity-intensive industrial processes.

We describe below the intellectual merit and broader impacts of the project:

Intellectual merit:

- A novel framework for DR scheduling of chemical processes was developed. It consists of embedding the scheduling-relevant process dynamics in the scheduling model. Shortcut models -referred to as "scale-bridging models" (SBMs) - are developed and used. SBMs represent the closed-loop dynamics of the process and capture its response to DR-relevant changes in production rate and/or product grade targets, and associated power demand. SBMs can be derived from first-principles process models via model reduction, or "learned" from routinely-available process operating data (evolution of, e.g., pressures, temperatures, flow rates).

- New design tools for flexible chemical processes were developed, where uncertainty related to, e.g., changes in electricity prices, production levels, is captured at the design stage. The currently-accepted paradigm for design under uncertainty is scenario-based: probability distributions of the uncertain parameters are sampled, resulting in a large number of scenarios and a high-dimensional optimization problem. We circumvented the discretization step by converting the design problem into an equivalent dynamic optimization formulation, whereby the uncertain parameters were represented as a set of disturbance variables. The resulting optimization problems can be solved more efficiently than their scenario-based equivalents. In support of the above, we generalized the pseudo-transient process modeling approach previously developed in our group.

- In collaboration with industrial partners, we pursued important applications: optimal design of amine-based carbon capture plants, of hydrogen production plants and of natural gas liquefaction facilities, and studied DR scheduling of air separation units and chlor-alkali plants.

We expect that the results will support the design of more flexible chemical plants, whose operators will be confident to participate in DR initiatives. Chemical processes have a strong potential for DR, and their engagement will lead to improving the sustainability of grid operations, e.g. by reducing the use of peaking power plants and associated fossil fuel consumption. More broadly, design under uncertainty is of high interest in other fields, and we expect that our results will aid researchers and practitioners in, e.g., mechanical and aerospace engineering working on the design of robust structures, civil and environmental engineers designing, e.g., water treatment systems.

Broader impacts:

The project supported one post-doctoral associate and partially supported five graduate students. Research results (in some cases, leveraging research funded from other sources, including the PI's NSF CAREER Award, US Department of Energy, and industry grants) were the basis of 26 peer-reviewed papers in academic journals, nine conference papers, four keynote/plenary lectures at major professional meetings, and numerous invited seminars and conference presentations. Three PhD theses were partially based on the results, which were also incorporated in the core Process Control course taught by the PI, and a new Product Design elective course that the PI developed in 2019.
